International Restrictions:
*Entry to Peru: The entry of foreign nationals who travel from the United Kingdom, South Africa and/or Brazil or who have stopped over in the United Kingdom, South Africa and/or Brazil in the last 14 calendar days and do not reside in Peru, is banned until 9 May.
Commercial international travel started on 5 October within the Latin American region. Passengers need to wear a face mask and a face shield/visor and need to have proof of a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR (molecular) test taken 72 hours before the commercial flight. You should arrange to take a private test.
*Quarantine requirements: All passengers arriving in Peru, irrespective of nationality, have to quarantine for 14 days. This can be in a home or accommodation anywhere in the country, in liaison with the health authorities. When the quarantine is to be completed outside Lima, you must arrive there within 24 hours after arrival in Peru.
If upon arrival in Peru you test positive, you will have to self-isolate in the Villa Panamericana or any other temporary centre in Lima or in the centres that the regional government assigns. You may end quarantine if you take an antigen test upon your arrival in the country and the result is negative. If you receive a positive result, you will need to quarantine where the health authorities decide.


Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Peru: On 15 March 2020, Peru announced a national State of Emergency, which has now been extended until at least 31 May April 2021. The latest tier-based regulations will also be in effect until at least 9 May.
Peru has been divided in three tier system (Extreme, Very High and High)
Extreme Tier: includes Chachapoyas province (region of Amazonas), Casma, Huaraz and Huarmey provinces (region of Ancash), Abancay and Andahuaylas provinces (region of Apurimac), Caylloma province (region of Arequipa), Zarumilla province (region of Tumbes), Piura and Sullana provinces (region of Piura), Chanchamayo, Tarma and Yauli provinces (region of Junin), Trujillo, Santiago de Chuco and Viru (region of La Libertad), Barranca, Huaura, Huaral, Cañete and Lima provinces (region of Lima), Casma, Huaraz and Huarmey provinces (region of Ancash), Tambopata province (region of Madre de Dios), Huamanga and Huanta provinces (region of Ayacucho), Anta, Cusco, La Convencion, Quispicanchi and Urubamba provinces (region of Cusco), Ica, Nazca and Pisco provinces (region of Ica), Chiclayo province (region of Lambayeque) Moyobamba and Rioja provinces (region of San Martin), Coronel Portillo province (region of Ucayali), Puno province (region of Puno), and Callao province.
• Curfew from 9pm to 4am from Monday to Saturday, and Sundays all day
• Ban on the use of private cars on Sundays
• Beaches are closed
• Interprovincial land passengers transport: open with 50% to 100% capacity, regulated by the Ministry of Transport
Activities in closed spaces:
• Casinos, gyms, movie theatres, performing arts: open with 20% capacity
• Shopping centres, galleries, department stores, shops: open with 20% capacity
• Groceries shops, supermarkets, markets, drugstores: open with 40% capacity.. Drugstore delivery service available 24 hours a day.
• Restaurants (internal areas with ventilation): open with 30% capacity and previous booking. Delivery service available until 11pm
• Churches: open with 20% capacity
• Libraries, museums, archaeological sites, cultural centres and galleries: open with 30% capacity
• Clubs and sport associations: open with 30% capacity
• Hairdressers, spas, facial massages, manicure, make up services (with ventilation): open with 40% capacity and previous appointments • Banks: open with 40% capacity
Activities in open spaces: No capacity limits and respecting protocols, with local governments’ previous authorisation
• Performing arts
• Cultural teaching
• Restaurants in open spaces
• Protected natural areas, botanic gardens and zoos
• Clubs and sport associations in open spaces
Very High Tier: includes the regions of Huanuco, Moquegua, Pasco, Tacna, Amazonas (except for Chachapoyas province), Apurimac (except for Andahuaylas and Abancay provinces), Tumbes (except for Zarumilla province), Piura (except for Piura and Sullana provinces), La Libertad (except for Trujillo, Santiago de Chuco and Viru provinces), Ancash (except for Casma, Huaraz and Huarmey provinces), Arequipa (except for Caylloma province), Ayacucho (except for Huamanga and Huanta provinces), Cajamarca (except for Cutervo and Jaen), Cusco (except for Cusco, Anta, La Convencion, Quisquipanchi and Urubamba provinces), Huancavelica (except for Huancavelica province), Ica (except for Ica, Nazca and Pisco provinces), Junin (except for Chanchamayo, Tarma and Yauliprovinces), Lambayeque (except for Chiclayo province), Lima (except for Barranca,Huaura, Huaral, Cañete and Lima provinces), Madre de Dios (except for Tambopata province), Ucayali (except for Coronel Portillo province), San Martin (except for Moyobamba and Rioja provinces) and Puno (except for Puno province).
• Curfew from 9pm to 4am daily
• Ban on the use of private cars on Sundays
• Beaches are closed

Nationwide regulations:
• Home deliveries will be permitted
• Restaurant take-outs will be permitted other than in curfew hours
• All commercial centres in the Very High and High tier regions must close two hours before curfew max, and in the Extreme tier regions 3 hours before curfew max
• when outside, children must be accompanied by an adult who lives with them and maintain a two-meter social distance
• it is recommended that people over 65 and those who have underlying health conditions stay at home, with some exceptions; risk groups must not receive visits at home and must avoid the physical contact with people who leave their home
• everyone must wear face masks outside of homes
• in addition to wearing a face mask, everyone must wear facial protectors (usually a clear plastic full-face covering) when on public transport
• everyone must wear two face masks and a facial protector while at places with crowding risk, such as shopping centres, markets, supermarkets, department stores, galleries, shops and drug stores.
• All types of social and family gatherings and visits, including political, civil and cultural events, are prohibited
Special regulations for Sunday 9 May (Mother’s Day):
• National curfew
• Ban on the use of private cars
• People will be allowed to go by foot or on a bike to buy essential items and medicine and for restaurant take outs
• Groceries shops, supermarkets, markets and drugstores can open from 4 am to 6 pm with their corresponding tiers’ capacity
• Drugstores’ 24 hours delivery service
• Restaurants delivery service: from 4 am to 11 pm
• The vaccination process will continue
Future changes to curfew rules will be announced by the government.
If you are leaving Peru and your approved period of stay in Peru has expired during the state of emergency, your visa fine should be waived by the Immigration authorities.
*Public places and services: Public places and services may be open or closed, depending on the tier level of the region.
